content: Mr. Ryan F Ingersoll is a 32 yrs year-old male who is referred to the hepatology clinic for evaluation of hepatitis B.. He first learned of having liver disease at age 18 yo when he was diagnosed with HBV when he attempted to give blood.. He was previously followed by Dr. Siddique at VMMC in Seattle.. He underwent a liver biopsy in 2007 that apparently showed fatty liver and reportedly showed mild fibrosis and unknown inflammation.. He underwent a FibroScan last year that showed no fibrosis.. He has never taken antiviral medications or had those recommended to him.

without long-term current use of insulin (HCC Code). 3/7/2019 NASH (nonalcoholic steatohepatitis). Other chronic nonalcoholic liver disease. 3/12/2019 Cirrhosis of liver without ascites. unspecified hepatic cirrhosis type (HCC Code). 3/12/2019 NASH (nonalcoholic steatohepatitis)

The patient was referred to transplant clinic due to elevated INR with referral labs making MELD score 15.. It is unclear why this occurred but patient not on medications to cause elevated INR and has no evidence of advanced liver disease to cause prolonged INR.. INR today is normal and MELD score is 6.. Fibroscan performed during office visit and confirms presence of steatosis but fibrosis staging is 6.1 kPa consistent with F0-1.. This is consistent with the absence of cirrhosis or portal hypertension on imaging and lack of clinical symptoms of chronic liver disease.. Based on these findings the patient does not require consideration of liver transplant at this time.

He reports an uncomplicated course and is not not believe that intraoperative liver biopsy that was performed.. He reports that procedure was done in Dothan, Alabama.. Subsequently followed by Dr. Rossignol due to persistently elevated liver tests and serologic work-up has been unremarkable.. Presumed diagnosed of NASH based on US imaging with steatosis but no evidence of advanced fibrosis.. Risk factor includes being over ideal body weight but denies hypertension, hyperlipidemia and diabetes.. He follows routinely with primary care for testing for these risk factors.

Consultation started: 11/20/2018 at 9:21 AM. Original Referring Provider: Randy Rossignol. Current Corresponding Physician:. UNOS Native Liver Diagnosis: Cirrhosis: Fatty Liver (Nash). Reason for Visit: evaluation for liver transplant. Subjective:

I have reviewed the patients history and I have personally examined the patient.. I have reviewed all of the available laboratory and radiological studies.. I agree with the findings and plan of care documented in Lucy Mathews note, with any additions or modifications noted below.. In summary, this is a pleasant 48-year-old female who was found to have fatty liver with no evidence of fibrosis.. She is also overweight.. Advised patient to eat healthy and exercise and we will see her back in our clinic in 6 months time with labs prior to that.

However, there is no evidence of fibrosis, which is reassuring.. We want to prevent any fibrosis in the future.. Therefore, it is important that she try to eat healthy and exercise and lose weight.. We will do MRE every 2 years or so to monitor fibrosis.. We understands that patient has phobia to vegetables; therefore, her dieting is somewhat limited.. However, we advised patient to continue to try her best.

We had a lengthy discussion with patient regarding her condition.. Explained to patient that she has fatty liver.. However, there is no evidence of fibrosis, which is reassuring.. We want to prevent any fibrosis in the future.. Therefore, it is important that she try to eat healthy and exercise and lose weight.. We will do MRE every 2 years or so to monitor fibrosis.

We want to prevent any fibrosis in the future.. Therefore, it is important that she try to eat healthy and exercise and lose weight.

Calcium, Serum 8.6 11/12/2019. ASSESSMENT: This is a 48-year-old female who was found to have:. 1.. Fatty liver based on MR elastography with no evidence of fibrosis.. 2.. Overweight with a body mass index of 37.2.
No current facility-administered medications for this visit.. PAST MEDICAL HISTORY:. 1.. Fatty liver based on CT scan as well as MR elastography with no evidence of fibrosis.. 2.. Sleep apnea.

The patient said that she had a history of fatty liver on an ultrasound more than 20 years ago.. The patient was counseled on diet and exercise; however, it is extremely difficult for her to lose weight.. The patient had complete liver workup done that was unremarkable.. The patient had an MR elastography on March 1, 2019, that showed moderate steatosis, mild fat, no evidence of fibrosis.. The patient was also started on vitamin E 800 daily in May of 2019.. The patient was found to have slightly elevated iron studies with a ferritin of 375, but iron saturation and total iron were completely normal.

Hepatology Problem List: (Based on detailed review of medical records and endoscopy and imaging reports, and supplemented by patient history.). 1.. Chronic inactive HBV, eAg-, DNA 3-6K/ALT 40-50s, and possible NAFLD.. Biopsy 2007 with steatosis and mild fibrosis, FibroScan 2016 F0 (both at OSH with no reports available). 1.1.. Likely acquired by vertical transmission (bio mother was an IVDU, patient was adopted)

Mr. Ryan F Ingersoll is a 32 yrs male who presents for evaluation and management of vertically-acquired chronic hepatitis B and NAFLD/NASH.. He has suffered no complications of chronic liver disease, such as ascites, variceal bleeding, hepatic encephalopathy, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, or hepatocellular carcinoma, and he has no indication of advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis based on history, exam, lab testing, or liver imaging.. His reported FibroScan last year with no fibrosis is quite reassuring.. I do think it is likely that he has both hepatitis B (chronic inactive stage, otherwise known as the carrier state) and NAFLD/NASH simultaneously, and the mild ALT elevation (30 u/L is the upper limit of normal in men) is likely to be driven by the latter condition.. For the hepatitis B, antiviral treatment is not indicated.. We will monitor his liver tests and HBV DNA every 6 months in case of a disease flare, and he will need liver cancer screening beginning at age 40 yo (q6 month ultrasounds).

(E66.9) OBESITY, BMI 35-39.9, ADULT. Mr. Ryan F Ingersoll is a 32 yrs male who presents for evaluation and management of vertically-acquired chronic hepatitis B and NAFLD/NASH.. He has suffered no complications of chronic liver disease, such as ascites, variceal bleeding, hepatic encephalopathy, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, or hepatocellular carcinoma, and he has no indication of advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis based on history, exam, lab testing, or liver imaging.. His reported FibroScan last year with no fibrosis is quite reassuring.. I do think it is likely that he has both hepatitis B (chronic inactive stage, otherwise known as the carrier state) and NAFLD/NASH simultaneously, and the mild ALT elevation (30 u/L is the upper limit of normal in men) is likely to be driven by the latter condition.. For the hepatitis B, antiviral treatment is not indicated.

(K75.81) NONALCOHOLIC STEATOHEPATITIS. (E66.9) OBESITY, BMI 35-39.9, ADULT. Mr. Ryan F Ingersoll is a 32 yrs male who presents for evaluation and management of vertically-acquired chronic hepatitis B and NAFLD/NASH.. He has suffered no complications of chronic liver disease, such as ascites, variceal bleeding, hepatic encephalopathy, spontaneous bacterial peritonitis, or hepatocellular carcinoma, and he has no indication of advanced fibrosis or cirrhosis based on history, exam, lab testing, or liver imaging.. His reported FibroScan last year with no fibrosis is quite reassuring.. I do think it is likely that he has both hepatitis B (chronic inactive stage, otherwise known as the carrier state) and NAFLD/NASH simultaneously, and the mild ALT elevation (30 u/L is the upper limit of normal in men) is likely to be driven by the latter condition.

Hepatology Problem List: (Based on detailed review of medical records and endoscopy and imaging reports, and supplemented by patient history.). 1.. Chronic inactive HBV, HBeAg-, DNA 5.8K IU/mL in 2017, and NAFLD/NASH.. Biopsy 2007 with steatosis and mild fibrosis, then FibroScan 2016 at no fibrosis (both at OSH with no reports available). 1.1.. Likely acquired by vertical transmission (mother was an IVDU, then patient was adopted)

He first learned of having liver disease at age 18 yo when he was diagnosed with HBV when he attempted to give blood.. He was previously followed by Dr. Siddique at VMMC in Seattle.. He underwent a liver biopsy in 2007 that apparently showed fatty liver and reportedly showed mild fibrosis and unknown inflammation.. He underwent a FibroScan last year that showed no fibrosis.. He has never taken antiviral medications or had those recommended to him.. For the NAFLD, he has worked to lose weight and has lost about 20 lbs over the last year.

It is unclear why this occurred but patient not on medications to cause elevated INR and has no evidence of advanced liver disease to cause prolonged INR.. INR today is normal and MELD score is 6.. Fibroscan performed during office visit and confirms presence of steatosis but fibrosis staging is 6.1 kPa consistent with F0-1.. This is consistent with the absence of cirrhosis or portal hypertension on imaging and lack of clinical symptoms of chronic liver disease.. Based on these findings the patient does not require consideration of liver transplant at this time.. The patient does appear to have chronic liver disease with prolonged history of elevated liver tests.
